body: A year and a half after work began on replacing water mains in their neighborhood, Carroll Gardens residents say problems with noise, vibrations and traffic have gotten worse recently. ''They're supposed to minimize vibrations,'' said Frank Vederame, who lives on First Place near Clinton Street, where the construction is taking place. But Mr.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Residents Are Rankled by Water-Main Construction

body: ON an August night eight years ago, my taxi slowed on Broadway at West 79th Street. A doorman in gold buttons swept open a gate, and we rolled into the courtyard of the Apthorp, a Renaissance-style building where a childhood friend lived. It became my first home in New York. For three weeks, I crashed in an elegant room whose walls smelled of musky
title: There's No Place Like Home. But There's . . . No Place.

title: EATING OUT

body: Almost a decade ago, a newcomer riding the elevated F train over the Gowanus Canal was told to look out the window. The subway still does not stop in Red Hook, but the new ''Neighborhood History
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK/GOWANUS; Frommer's It's Not; Guidebook Burnishes a Rugged Image

body: Agents with the United States Customs Service seized 1,100 pounds of cocaine at a two-story house in Deer Park on Tuesday, and officials said they believed it was one of the largest seizures of the drug ever made on Long Island. The authorities arrested five men in connection with the seizure, and estimated that the street value of the cocaine was
title: U.S. Agents Seize Cocaine At L.I. House And Arrest 5

body: The people of New York knew that it would have to end, the way they know that the winds of November will soon be blustering up Broadway. Still, this thing of theirs, this World Series, seemed to end all too soon. And so they stumbled into yesterday's morning light, resigned to put aside the whimsies of fantasy for the realities of life. There are a
title: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES; A Big Fantasy Camp Suddenly Evaporates

body: To the Editor: Re: ''Obsessive? No, Just Looking for a Parking Space'' (Oct. 8): Why should we pity anyone who can't find a free parking space? In your article, a deputy commissioner of the Transportation Department, Michael Primeggia, virtually brags about being able to find parking for his household's two (!) cars every night on his block. This
title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.

body: Worried that most public high schools are not good enough for their children, middle-class and affluent parents across New York City have begun campaigning for a return to the traditional neighborhood high school. The movement, based in affluent enclaves from the Upper East Side to Park Slope in Brooklyn and Riverdale in the Bronx, is led by
title: Parents Want High Schoolers Closer to Home

body: Four of the nine members of Brooklyn's Community School Board 15 have asked Schools Chancellor Harold O. The request comes less than a year after the District 15 board
title: Levy Is Urged to Consider Firing a Brooklyn Superintendent

title: Brooklyn School District Exceeded Spending Caps for Conferences, Audit Says

body: ON a stormy evening last May, silvery voices could be heard floating down the halls of Public School 321 in Park Slope. ''To-may-to! To-mah-to! Po-tay-to! Po-tah-to! title: The Quest to Reinvent John Jay

body: FRIENDS say it is nearly impossible to discourage Maggie McGuire. She could read the darkest novel while rain poured outside and still not lose hope or humor. ''She's so approachable and open and fun,'' said Stacey Savage Constas, a college friend. ''People love to be around her. We used to say, 'Maggie McGuire, girl on fire.' '' After graduating
title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; Maggie McGuire and Kurt Wallace

author: Diane Cardwell is an editor at the magazine.
body: A few years ago, when I moved near Smith Street -- a dusty stretch running through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens -- it seemed happily mired in the 1950's. Dotted with members-only social clubs and old men playing cards in front of shuttered storefronts, the area felt untouched by the relentless pace of Manhattan
title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00; A Street Grows In Brooklyn

body: Much like Manhattan, Brooklyn has never had a boroughwide multiple listing of homes for sale. body: AT dusk on a midsummer evening, not long after trading on Wall Street has closed for the day, nine people gather in a Greenwich Village living room to talk money. title: The Pursuit of Less

body: ON a breezy Saturday afternoon, Rawle George rode his bike into Prospect Park, weaved around the families barbecuing hot dogs, and coasted past a crowded Little League game. Stopping in a field of people flying kites and playing Frisbee, he scanned the scene until his eye hooked onto one object: a white ball being kicked into the air. Mr. George
title: Years Pass. The Game Endures.

body: The death of a 10-year-old Brooklyn boy in February has been ruled a homicide, according to a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office, who said the child died of starvation and dehydration. title: Months Later, Boy's Death Is Ruled Homicide by Starvation

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; As Pipes Are Patched, Tempers Rise

body: Clarence Eckerson's apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is a nine-minute walk from the F train. To speed his morning commute, he occasionally bikes to the station, but he said there were few places to lock his 18-speed. ''There were bicycles locked to trees,'' Mr. Eckerson said. But then, about three weeks ago, he came home to a pleasant
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Metal Bike Racks Sprout Citywide, Bringing Joy to Urban Cyclists

body: FOR all the fuss over the glut of new restaurants in Brooklyn, you would think that the Dodgers had come back to town or that, finally, another tree had grown. title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Defining Moment In Brooklyn

body: SHORTLY after sundown on Dec. 9, a diner walked into Banania Cafe on Smith Street in Brooklyn, sat at a corner table and ordered oysters. title: On Smith Street, a Dream Made Real

title: Verdict Divides Officers But Leaves Few Happy

title: IN BRIEF; Web Site's New Baby Is a City Baby Store

title: $25 AND UNDER; A French Restaurant Family Plants Roots in Brooklyn
